Israeli forces kill Palestinian youth near Jit in the occupied West Bank

title: Trump says 'we will get it done' in the Middle East
summary:
Trump says 'we will get it done' in the Middle East

Submitted by MEE staff on Sun, 09/28/2025 - 16:56
The US president hints at 'something special' in talks to end war in Gaza
U.S. President Donald Trump speaks at the White House in Washington, DC, 25 September 2025 (Reuters)
Off

US President Donald Trump voiced optimism on Sunday about reaching a deal to end the war in Gaza, saying there was ‚Äúa real chance for greatness in the Middle East,‚Äù ahead a meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Monday.

Trump did not share details of what a potential ceasefire-for-captives agreement might look like, but Vice President JD Vance told Fox News that senior US officials were engaged in ‚Äúvery complicated‚Äù negotiations with both Israeli and Arab counterparts.

‚ÄúWe have a real chance for Greatness in the Middle East. All are on board for something special, first time ever. We will get it done,‚Äù Trump wrote in a Truth Social post.

According to administration officials, Trump‚Äôs discussions with Netanyahu are aimed at laying out a framework for an agreement.

On Friday, Trump described talks with regional leaders as intense, adding that both Israel and Hamas were aware of the ongoing contacts, which he said would continue ‚Äúas long as required.‚Äù

Vance said he was ‚Äúcautiously hopeful‚Äù about reaching a deal.

‚ÄúI feel more optimistic about where we are right now than where we have been at any point in the last few months, but let‚Äôs be realistic, these things can get derailed at the very last minute,‚Äù he said.

He noted that the proposed plan centres on three priorities: securing the return of all captives, ending Hamas‚Äôs threat to Israel, and increasing humanitarian aid to Gaza.

Trump proposal to permanently end war abandons 'Gaza Riviera' plan: Report
Read More ¬ª

‚ÄúSo I think we‚Äôre close to accomplishing all three of those objectives,‚Äù Vance said.

The US also presented a 21-point Middle East peace plan at the United Nations in New York last week.

The plan outlines steps including the return of all hostages, a halt to Israeli strikes on Qatar, and renewed Israeli-Palestinian dialogue aimed at ‚Äúpeaceful coexistence.‚Äù

That plan calls for the return of all hostages, living and dead, no further Israeli attacks on Qatar and renewed Israeli-Palestinian dialogue aimed at ‚Äúpeaceful coexistence.‚Äù

Also included in the proposal were the deployment of an international force to Gaza, and Israel agreeing not to annex the territory and drive out Palestinians living there.

Hamas said on Saturday that it had not been presented with the US plan.

title: Israeli army destroys multistorey building in Gaza City assault
summary:
Israeli army destroys multistorey building in Gaza City assault

The Israeli army has demolished a multistorey building in Gaza City, just under an hour after ordering residents in several neighbourhoods to evacuate.

The military‚Äôs forced displacement notice targeted families in Remal, Sabra, the port district and parts of Beirut Street, pushing yet more Palestinians from their homes as bombardments continue.

title: Over 66,000 Palestinians killed in Gaza: Health Ministry
summary:
Over 66,000 Palestinians killed in Gaza: Health Ministry

The Palestinian Health Ministry on Sunday said that Israel has killed over 66,000 Palestinians across the Gaza Strip. 

The ministry noted that the death toll had climbed to 66,005, with a further 168,162 wounded since October 7. 

Among the death were 79 who were brought to hospitals in the past 24 hours.

title: Jordan's king says details of Trump's Gaza plan 'in line' with what has been agreed: Reuters
summary:
Jordan's king says details of Trump's Gaza plan 'in line' with what has been agreed: Reuters

Jordan's King Abdullah said on Sunday that many details of US President Donald Trump's plan to end the war in Gaza were "in line with what has been agreed upon", the Jordanian state news agency reported.

He did not give further details on the plan itself or what it entailed.

Trump said on Friday that he was close to forging a deal to end the war in Gaza.

title: Global Sumud Flotilla set sail from Crete for final leg
summary:
Global Sumud Flotilla set sail from Crete for final leg

The Global Sumud Flotilla has set sail again for Gaza after pausing for several days in Greek waters for repairs.

Organisers said Greek vessels joined their flotilla, meaning 47 boats have now joined their attempt to break Israel's naval blockade and deliver aid to Gaza. 

"Brothers and sisters in Gaza, we sail with hope in our hearts. Your resilience is our compass, your struggle is our struggle. Together, we will break the silence of the siege," the Global Sumud Flotilla wrote on social media.

Earlier on Wednesday, the flotilla was struck in international waters off Crete by drones armed with stun grenades and irritants, which caused damage but no injuries.

Israel did not comment on the incident but has criticised the flotilla as "intended to serve Hamas".

Earlier on Sunday, Italy's Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani repeated a proposal made last week for the flotilla to take the aid to Cyprus for eventual distribution in Gaza by the Roman Catholic Church. The flotilla rejected the suggestion.

title: Afternoon update
summary:
Afternoon update

Good afternoon,

If you are joining us, here are the latest updates on the situation in Gaza.

  • The Palestinian health ministry said Israel has killed over 66,000 Palestinians across the Gaza Strip since October 2023.
  • Witnesses and medics told Reuters that tanks were advancing deeper into several densely populated neighbourhoods of Gaza City, with hospitals unable to respond to dozens of desperate calls for help.
  • US President Donald Trump said on Sunday that there was a "real chance for greatness in the Middle East", with a potential peace deal, without providing specific details or a timetable, after saying he was close to forging an agreement to end the war in Gaza.
  • Hamas's armed wing said it has lost contact with two captives in Gaza during intense fighting. The Qassam Brigades demanded Israel halt air sorties for 24 hours in part of Gaza City to remove the captives from danger.
  • The Israeli army claimed it had killed five Palestinian fighters as part of its military campaign to take control of Gaza City. In a military update, the army said it struck 140 military targets, including military infrastructure and fighters in Gaza City.

title: Trump says 'we will get it done' in the Middle East
summary:
Trump says 'we will get it done' in the Middle East

US President Donald Trump said on Sunday that there was "a real chance for greatness in the Middle East" without providing specific details or a timetable, days after saying he was close to forging a deal to end the war in Gaza.

"We have a real chance for Greatness in the Middle East. All are on board for something special, first time ever. We will get it done," he said in a Truth Social post.

Trump will meet Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Monday at the White House with the aim of reaching a framework for a deal, according to administration officials.

Trump said on Friday that talks on Gaza with Middle Eastern nations were intense and that Israel and Hamas were aware of the discussions, which he said would continue as long as required.

title: Hamas lose contact with two captives during Gaza fighting
summary:
Hamas lose contact with two captives during Gaza fighting

Hamas's armed wing said on Sunday it lost contact with two captives, Matan Angrest and Omri Miran, during Israeli military operations in two Gaza City neighbourhoods.

In a statement, the al-Qassam Brigades said it had demanded that Israel halt air sorties for 24 hours, starting at 6:00 p.m., in part of Gaza City to remove the captives from danger.

title: Visual evidence disproves Israeli claim that Nasser Hospital strike targeted Hamas camera: Reuters
summary:
Visual evidence disproves Israeli claim that Nasser Hospital strike targeted Hamas camera: Reuters

A Reuters analysis of visual evidence and other information about Israel's attack on a Gaza hospital last month, which killed five journalists, contradicts Israel's explanation that it targeted a Hamas camera.

The Israel Army attacked Gaza's Nasser Hospital on August 25, killing 22 people, including five journalists, who routinely gathered on the hospital stairwell landing to record from a high vantage point and file reports from Gaza's Khan Yunis area.

Among the journalists killed were Mariam Dagga, a photojournalist who freelanced for The Associated Press, and Hussam al-Masri, a photojournalist for Reuters.

The army's initial review into the strike showed that troops targeted a Hamas camera because it was filming them from the hospital, according to a military official who spoke with Reuters. The official said troops viewed the camera with suspicion because it was covered by a towel and because Hamas has used cameras to plan attacks, and a decision was made to destroy it.

title: EU welcomes re-opening of bridge between Jordan and Israel
summary:
EU welcomes re-opening of bridge between Jordan and Israel

The European Union has welcomed the reopening of the Israeli-controlled King Hussein (Allenby) Bridge after Israel reportedly closed the gateway, following an attack on Israeli forces stationed at one of the checkpoints that killed two Israeli soldiers. 

The Allenby Bridge is the only gateway for Palestinians in the West Bank to exit the occupied territory without entering Israel. 

In a statement, the EU‚Äôs high representative said: ‚ÄúThe decision by Israeli authorities on September 23 to close the Allenby/King Hussein Bridge crossing to passenger movement in both directions, as well as to cargo movement, negatively affects freedom of movement between the West Bank and Jordan, and undermines humanitarian aid efforts to Gaza.

‚ÄúThe Allenby/King Hussein Bridge crossing, like other border crossings, must remain open to ensure the effectiveness of humanitarian relief operations, as a quarter of humanitarian supplies reach Gaza through Jordan via UN mechanism 2720.‚Äù

title: Palestinians trapped as Israeli tanks advance deeper into Gaza City
summary:
Palestinians trapped as Israeli tanks advance deeper into Gaza City

Israeli tanks advanced deeper into several densely populated neighbourhoods of Gaza City on Sunday, with health authorities unable to respond to dozens of desperate calls for help.

Witnesses and medics told Reuters that the tanks entered key residential areas including Sabra, Tal al-Hawa, Sheikh Radwan and al-Nasser. 

The incursions mark a significant escalation, bringing Israeli forces closer to the centre and western parts of the city, where hundreds of thousands of displaced Palestinians are currently seeking shelter.

Local health officials reported receiving dozens of urgent calls from civilians trapped in affected areas but said they were unable to respond due to the intensity of the military operation and the ongoing bombardment.

READ MORE HERE: Israeli tanks advance deeper into Gaza City, trapping civilians

summary: The former secretary of High Council for Human rights of the Judiciary of Islamic Republic of Iran said the United States and the West are trying to make knowledge exclusive and deprive others of it, but this is completely against the essence of science.

title: Larijani: Iran stands by Lebanon and Resistance
summary: Top security official, Ali Larijani, met with Hezbollah Secretary-General Sheikh Naim Qassem, where he reaffirmed Iran‚Äôs unwavering support for Lebanon and the Resistance.

title: Iran does not need permission from anyone to boost defensive capabilities: Senior commander
summary: Brigadier General Abolfazl Shekarchi said that Iran‚Äôs enemies, despite possessing nuclear weapons and missiles carrying nuclear warheads, ignore the inalienable right of the Iranian nation to have peaceful nuclear energy.

title: In photos: Iran‚Äôs Armenian Christians honor St. George in Tehran
summary: The commemoration of St. George was held at St. George Church, located on Vahdat-e Eslami Street in Tehran, on September 26-27, 2025.

title: Zarif: Failure to force Iran to surrender made E3 revive terminated resolution
summary: Mohammad-Javad Zarif said the E3 restored terminated resolution since they had failed to bring Iran to its knees.

title: Army Chief vows swift response against enemy missteps
summary: Hatami described the military‚Äôs preparedness against possible threats as permanent and highly valuable.

title: Top general: Unity of armed forces guarantees national security
summary: Major General Mousavi stressed that coordination, synergy, and unity of the Armed Forces are the factors behind the defeat of the enemy.

title: Terminated UN resolutions create no obligations for Iran: Foreign Ministry
summary: Iran‚Äôs Foreign Ministry rejected US and E3 claims on reinstating UN sanctions, affirming the resolutions ‚Äì once terminated under the JCPOA ‚Äìcreate no obligations for Iran and other member states of the world body.

title: Speaker Ghalibaf rejects UN sanctions, emphasizes national strength
summary: Iran‚Äôs Parliament Speaker Mohammad-Bagher Ghalibaf said that there is no obligation to adhere to illegal UN resolutions against the Islamic Republic.

title: Iranian universities call for global campaign to protect scientists after Israeli assassination
summary: Iranian universities and academic centers called on the awakened conscience of the world to join a global campaign titled Protect Scientists.

title: Abzas Media journalists transferred over 250 kilometres from Baku
summary: The three women journalists ‚Äî Sevinj Abbasova, Elnara Gasimova, and Nargiz Absalamova ‚Äî were not notified of the transfer beforehand.

title: Azerbaijani petrol tycoon arrested for ‚Äòcontaminating‚Äô crude from different sources
summary: Adnan Ahmadzada, a former SOCAR employee, has been remanded to four months of pre-trial detention.

title: Georgian activist sentenced to 20 days in prison
summary: Tbilisi City Court has sentenced anti-government activist Isako Devidze to 20 days of administrative detention. He had been charged with petty hooliganism and disobedience to police, charges frequently used against government critics. Devidze was detained in central Tbilisi near the parliament on Tuesday night, following a demonstration marking the 300th day of the daily anti-government protests. title: Russian Parliament approves the renaming of three Cossack villages in Chechnya
summary: The three villages will be given Chechen names instead.

title: Abkhazian‚ÄìKorean cultural centre opens in Seoul
summary: The opening ceremony earlier in September was attended by Abkhazian Culture Minister Daur Kove.

title: Three more Georgian opposition candidates quit amid claims of state pressure
summary: The announcement followed a previous withdrawal of a mayoral candidate in favour of the ruling party.
